messageBody:
>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>Sent: Tuesday, October 12, 2004 4:16 PM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] Definitions question
>
>
>
>Chappell, Simon P wrote:
>> We're having some "robust" discussions about testing here
>and one of the
>> big issues concerns correct nomenclature for testing types
>and levels
>> and scopes. Does anyone have any book recommendations to help with
>> industry accepted terms and definitions? I have seen
>references to "The
>> Art of Software Testing" by Glenford Myers that describe it as the
>> seminal work on the matter. Is that book worth getting? Is there a
>> website anywhere that has "standard" definitions that my
>co-workers and
>> I can use for enlightenment on this matter?
>>
>> All wisdom on this matter will be greatly appreciated.
>
>Here's wisdom that nevertheless doesn't help you: it doesn't matter.

JB, that's good wisdom, but you're right, it doesn't answer my question.

>If they're getting hung up on what words mean in some ethereal objective
>sense, rather than simply finding a workable vocabulary to help with
>their current discussion, then I have to wonder whether they
>care about
>communicating at all.

We actually are working on the shared vocabiulary at this time, which is why I asked. I would prefer that we use accepted terminology, but I need some definitive source to show people, so that they will accept it. Otherwise, we'll be using the terminology that the process police give us. :-(

Remember: large companies don't do anything until they've defined what they're gonna call everything.

You know you're up against an interesting challenge, when one of the questions from an attendee is "What's a unit?"

Simon
